awd_titl_txt: 2022 Genomic Instability (GRS)-The Influence of Chromosome Architecture and Cell Cycle on Repair and Maintenance of the Genome
awd_abstract_narration:
The award will provide support for graduate students and post-doctoral researchers to attend the 2022 Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Genome Instability (July 9-10, 2022 in Ventura Beach, CA). The GRS will be held just prior to the associated Gordon Research Conference (GRC; July 10-15, 2022). These two meetings bring together young and established scientists from multiple disciplines who are addressing a broad range of questions about DNA repair and genome maintenance, from tool development to mechanism and function. The GRS, in particular, enables a diverse group of early career scientists to discuss current research through seminars and poster sessions, exchange new ideas, technologies and resources informally, and develop their professional network. Hence this conference will facilitate training and professional development of the next generation of scientists in this rapidly expanding area, including underrepresented minorities. The GRS program includes a panel discussion on career choices with accomplished scientists in different professions. The GRS also serves as a career development experience for the co-chairs and organizers, who are postdocs. 

Genome maintenance and stability are essential to cellular function, stable inheritance, and organismal phenotype. The intricate monitoring, signaling and, when necessary, repair systems are also important because their dysfunction leads to a wide range of important diseases. The GRS and GRC serve as a vital link for investigators around the world to share their latest, often unpublished discoveries, discuss pioneering ideas and launch new collaborations. Topics at the forefront of biochemistry, molecular genetics and cell biology of DNA repair pathways will be covered, among others.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Gordon Research Seminar on Genomic Instability was a unique forum for graduate students, post-docs, and other scientists with comparable levels of experience and education to present and exchange new data and cutting edge ideas. Attendance at the Genomic Instability GRS was a highly recommended prelude to the Genomic Instability GRC.

This meeting highlighted the influence of chromatin state and cell cycle on pathways that signal and repair DNA double-strand breaks and damage associated with replication stress. Additionally, this GRS featured a keynote presentation by Dr. Irene Chiolo and selected talks and posters by graduate students and post-doctoral researchers. There was also be a career panel discussion with researchers from academia and industry. 

It was a unique meeting to foster constructive scientific discussion on a wide variety of topics related to DNA repair, recombination and replication between graduate students, postdocs and a small number of established scientists. This GRS created an inclusive environment to facilitate collegiality amongst participants to both inspire and discuss their research in the context of recent advances in the field.

Seminars are geared towards graduate students and postdocs as a pre-cursor to the associated GRC meeting. It was an excellent opportunity for the free and open discussion of ideas at the frontiers of science and technology.
